channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: 75 Arrested in European Crackdown on Art Trafficking
item.description: The European police recovered about 3,500 stolen archaeological artifacts and other artworks, Spain’s Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Lanzarote Journal: Undersea Museum Keeps Fish Feeding and Its Social Commentary Biting
item.media:description: Jason deCaires Taylor, a British sculptor, outside his studio in Lanzarote, Spain.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: An installation of 300 statues off a Spanish island forms an artificial reef and addresses issues like Europe’s migration crisis, and the destruction of ocean reefs.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Theresa May Is Grilled Over U.K. Missile Test Failure
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May spoke about Britain’s nuclear weapons program on the BBC. She would not say whether she knew about the reported failure of an unarmed missile during a test.
item.description: The prime minister refused to comment about the 2016 missile test or about reports that its failure had been covered up by her predecessor.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Cubans Newly Blocked at U.S. Border Place Hopes in Trump
item.media:description: A pastor last week led Cubans in prayer in Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, near the United States border. The Obama administration’s decision to end a policy granting special immigration privileges to Cubans has left many in limbo.
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.description: The Obama administration ended special immigration privileges for Cubans after normalizing relations with Cuba. Now migrants arrive into a desperate limbo after an arduous journey.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Leaders Abroad, Joyful or Wary, Face Uncertainty of Trump Era
item.media:description: Protesters set fire to an American flag with a picture of President Trump’s face outside the United States Embassy in Manila on Friday.
item.description: Germany’s vice chancellor said the inaugural speech reflected a “drastic radicalization” of U.S. politics. But some world leaders embraced the new reality.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, STEVEN ERLANGER and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: ‘Gambia Is Back Again,’ but Its New Leader Is Still in Senegal
item.media:description: A ferry carrying people who fled Gambia arrived back in the country after the former president, Yahya Jammeh, relinquished power on Saturday.
item.description: President Adama Barrow has been in the neighboring nation for a week. The incumbent he defeated, Yahya Jammeh, had refused to step down until Saturday.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: 7 Questions for Gambia’s New President, Adama Barrow
item.media:description: President Adama Barrow of Gambia during an interview in Dakar, Senegal, on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Barrow was sworn in from Senegal when his predecessor refused to cede power. Now, preparing to take over, he discussed his vision for the nation.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: A Colonial-Era Wound Opens in Namibia
item.media:description: Protesters splashed paint on a statue in Swakopmund, Namibia, that commemorates German soldiers who helped crush a rebellion by the Herero and Nama ethnic groups.
item.description: More than a century after the genocide of two African ethnic groups, a city that retains strong German ties is divided over the fate of a war memorial.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: To Secular Bangladeshis, Textbook Changes Are a Harbinger
item.media:description: Students at a madrasa, or Islamic school, last year in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Changes were recently made to textbooks after requests from conservative Islamic religious scholars.
item.description: Revisions sought by Islamic scholars were barely noticeable to the public, but intellectuals see them as government accommodation of a larger shift toward radical Islam.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: Train Derails in Southern India, Killing Dozens
item.media:description: Bodies were lined up along the road at the site of the derailment.
item.description: Rescue workers struggled into the morning to pull the injured and dead from the train in the latest disaster for India’s overburdened railway.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Claim Deadly Market Bombing
item.media:description: The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the blast Saturday in Parachinar, capital of the Kurram tribal region.
item.description: The blast ended a long lull in militant violence in Parachinar, a Shiite town that has been a center of resistance to the Pakistani Taliban.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Trump Presidency Is Already Altering Israeli-Palestinian Politics
item.media:description: Speculation swirled that the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv might move to Jerusalem.
item.description: The transition, and questions surrounding it, rippled through issues including the location of the American Embassy and whether Palestinians are on the edge of a renewed revolt.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER

item.title: Renewed Fighting and Drone Strikes in Yemen Kill About 75
item.media:description: An airstrike by the Saudi-led coalition hit an army base in Sana, Yemen, on Sunday.
item.description: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition killed more than 50 Houthi rebels, and two suspected U.S. drone attacks killed 10 militants with Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: What in the World: For a Modest Price, the Streets of Paris Can Be Yours
item.media:description: Some Paris streets still have visible cobblestone paving, but on many the stones have been buried under asphalt and are often torn up during construction. Rather than dump them, the city has started to salvage and sell the stones.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Cobblestones have lined Paris’s streets since the 12th century. When the city began selling used ones, an entrepreneur saw a chance to make unique souvenirs.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Oil Producers Claim Progress in Curbing the World’s Daily Supply
item.description: A group of OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers have joined forces to reduce the daily amount of oil on sale by 1.8 million barrels in the first six months of this year.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: For France’s Left, a Time of Crisis
item.media:description: Manuel Valls, the former Socialist prime minister, at a debate at a union center in Puteaux, France, this month. France’s presidential election is being watched as a barometer of European disaffection.
item.description: The governing Socialists are deeply unpopular and given little chance in the coming presidential election, as European voters abandon the left.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Marine Le Pen Extols Far Right During Speech in Germany
item.media:description: In Koblenz, Germany, on Saturday, Marine Le Pen, leader of the National Front in France, said that the far right would awake in Europe this year.
item.description: The triumph of anti-Europeans in Britain and Donald J. Trump in the United States has galvanized the Continent’s far-right parties, who are wooing disillusioned voters.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Avalanche Death Toll in Italy Reaches 5 as Search of Hotel Rubble Continues
item.media:description: Rescuers at the avalanche-hit Hotel Rigopiano, near the village of Farindola, Italy.
item.description: Rescue workers on Saturday pulled three more bodies from the rubble and snow that covered a hotel in the Apennine Mountains when it was hit by an avalanche caused by an earthquake on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Historian’s Latest Book on Mao Turns Acclaim in China to Censure
item.media:description: The Chinese author Yang Jisheng in 2013. Mr. Yang, a noted chronicler of the Mao era, has published “The World Turned Upside Down,” a history of the Cultural Revolution.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Yang Jisheng’s effort to “recover the history” of the Cultural Revolution has become part of the struggle over China’s Communist past, which has widened under President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Defeated Gambian Leader Ends Standoff and Boards a Flight Into Exile
item.media:description: A ferry bringing back people who fled Gambia because of its political crisis arrived at the port in Banjul on Saturday.
item.description: Yahya Jammeh, who was defeated in an election last month, announced that he would step down, sending a wave of relief through the nation.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Trump Inspires Cheers, and Alarm, Around the World
item.media:description: The newly formed European Trump Society in Sofia, Bulgaria, watched live coverage of President Trump’s inauguration on Friday.
item.media:credit: Boryana Dimitrova Katsarova for The New York Times
item.description: The president’s inauguration was a cause of worry for many around the world, but some greeted it with wine and celebration.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: A Third of Afghans Will Need Aid This Year, U.N. Says
item.description: The world body launched an appeal Saturday for more than half a billion dollars to help civilians feeling the brunt of an intensifying war.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: The Neediest Cases: After Escape From Syria, Another Dangerous Foe: Diabetes
item.media:description: Nisreen al-Najjar’s son Hisham, center, at home in Jordan. Hisham has Type 1 diabetes.
item.media:credit: Nadia Bseiso for The New York Times
item.description: A Neediest Cases beneficiary agency tries to help bridge a health care gap for a young refugee in Jordan, far from home.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Opinion: How Not to Be Afraid
item.description: I had an apocalyptic evangelical upbringing, a father who told me too much about the Holocaust, and a grandfather who was a neo-Nazi and Jew — and I was terrified.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL MARIE STONE

item.title: Opinion: I Went to Aleppo to Study. I Left in a Convoy of Refugees.
item.media:description: A man carrying the body of his child, who was killed in an airstrike on eastern Aleppo, in 2016.
item.description: In the last weeks of the siege, we were desperate for the world to hear and help us.
item.dc:creator: LINA SHAMY
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: South Sudan Cannot Be Allowed to Collapse
item.media:description: Peacekeeping troops patrol at night in the town of Abyei, disputed territory between Sudan and South Sudan, in December.
item.media:credit: Albert Gonzalez Farran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Current leaders on all sides must be given a graceful exit and guarantees they won’t face criminal prosecution.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW S. NATSIOS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
